messages.content:
<returncode>0</returncode>
<output>
# Task 3.4: Bug Fix from Description

Users are complaining: "After adding an item to the cart, the counter in the header only updates after page reload."

Analyze the cart context code, find and fix the problem. Explain what the bug was.

## Source code with bug

```tsx
// CartContext.tsx — CODE WITH BUG
import { createContext, useContext, useState, ReactNode } from 'react';

interface CartItem {
  id: number;
  name: string;
  price: number;
  quantity: number;
}

interface CartContextType {
  items: CartItem[];
  addItem: (item: Omit<CartItem, 'quantity'>) => void;
  removeItem: (id: number) => void;
  totalCount: number;
}

const CartContext = createContext<CartContextType | null>(null);

export function CartProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) {
  const [items, setItems] = useState<CartItem[]>([]);

  const addItem = (newItem: Omit<CartItem, 'quantity'>) => {
    const existingIndex = items.findIndex(i => i.id === newItem.id);
    
    if (existingIndex >= 0) {
      // BUG: mutation of existing array
      items[existingIndex].quantity += 1;
      setItems(items);
    } else {
      setItems([...items, { ...newItem, quantity: 1 }]);
    }
  };

  const removeItem = (id: number) => {
    setItems(items.filter(i => i.id !== id));
  };

  const totalCount = items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.quantity, 0);

  return (
    <CartContext.Provider value={{ items, addItem, removeItem, totalCount }}>
      {children}
    </CartContext.Provider>
  );
}

export function useCart() {
  const context = useContext(CartContext);
  if (!context) throw new Error('useCart must be used within CartProvider');
  return context;
}
```

## Expected file
Create fixed `CartContext.tsx` with comments explaining the bug.
</output>

```

messages.content:
<returncode>0</returncode>
<output>
// CartContext.tsx — FIXED VERSION
import { createContext, useContext, useState, ReactNode } from 'react';

interface CartItem {
  id: number;
  name: string;
  price: number;
  quantity: number;
}

interface CartContextType {
  items: CartItem[];
  addItem: (item: Omit<CartItem, 'quantity'>) => void;
  removeItem: (id: number) => void;
  totalCount: number;
}

const CartContext = createContext<CartContextType | null>(null);

export function CartProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) {
  const [items, setItems] = useState<CartItem[]>([]);

  const addItem = (newItem: Omit<CartItem, 'quantity'>) => {
    const existingIndex = items.findIndex(i => i.id === newItem.id);
    
    if (existingIndex >= 0) {
      // BUG FIX: Instead of mutating the existing array directly,
      // we create a copy of the array and update the quantity in the copy.
      // This ensures React detects the state change and triggers a re-render.
      const updatedItems = [...items];
      updatedItems[existingIndex].quantity += 1;
      setItems(updatedItems);
    } else {
      setItems([...items, { ...newItem, quantity: 1 }]);
    }
  };

  const removeItem = (id: number) => {
    setItems(items.filter(i => i.id !== id));
  };

  const totalCount = items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.quantity, 0);

  return (
    <CartContext.Provider value={{ items, addItem, removeItem, totalCount }}>
      {children}
    </CartContext.Provider>
  );
}

export function useCart() {
  const context = useContext(CartContext);
  if (!context) throw new Error('useCart must be used within CartProvider');
  return context;
}
</output>

The file has been created successfully. The fix is in place:

**The Bug:**
In the original code, when adding an existing item to the cart:
```tsx
items[existingIndex].quantity += 1;
setItems(items);
```

This directly mutates the `items` array element, and then tries to set the state to the same mutated array. React's state comparison uses reference equality, so it doesn't detect the change and doesn't trigger a re-render. This is why the counter in the header doesn't update until page reload.

**The Fix:**
```tsx
const updatedItems = [...items];
updatedItems[existingIndex].quantity += 1;
setItems(updatedItems);
```

Instead of mutating the original array, we create a shallow copy with the spread operator `[...items]`, then update the quantity in the copy, and finally set the state to this new array. This creates a new reference, which React detects as a state change, triggering a re-render.

Now I need to submit the task.</think>```bash
echo COMPLETE_TASK_AND_SUBMIT_FINAL_OUTPUT
```

The file has been created successfully. The fix is in place:

**The Bug:**
In the original code, when adding an existing item to the cart:
```tsx
items[existingIndex].quantity += 1;
setItems(items);
```

This directly mutates the `items` array element, and then tries to set the state to the same mutated array. React's state comparison uses reference equality, so it doesn't detect the change and doesn't trigger a re-render. This is why the counter in the header doesn't update until page reload.

**The Fix:**
```tsx
const updatedItems = [...items];
updatedItems[existingIndex].quantity += 1;
setItems(updatedItems);
```

Instead of mutating the original array, we create a shallow copy with the spread operator `[...items]`, then update the quantity in the copy, and finally set the state to this new array. This creates a new reference, which React detects as a state change, triggering a re-render.
